item.title: The number of monogenic subsemigroups of the full transformation monoid
item.description: Mathematics In this post we show how to count the number of monogenic subsemigroups of the full transformation monoid up to isomorphism. Throughout this post, we denote the natural numbers \(\{0, 1, \ldots\}\) by \({\mathbb{N}}\). The symmetric group and full transformation semigroup on \(\{1, \ldots, n\}\), \(n\in {\mathbb{N}}\), are denoted \(S_n\) and \(T_n\), respectively. A subsemigroup of a semigroup \(S\) is monogenic if it can be generated by a single element; monogenic subsemigroups of finite groups are just cyclic subgroups.
